definition[0]: to put too many things or people on or into something
example[0]: Be careful not to overload the washing machine.
example[1]: The bus was overloaded with tourists and their luggage.
definition[1]: to put too much electricity through an electrical system or piece of equipment
definition[2]: to give someone too much work or information to deal with
example[3]: All the staff are overloaded with work.
definition[3]: to give someone more work, information etc than they can deal with
example[4]: Don’t overload your buyer with too much information.
definition[4]: if something is overloaded with a particular problem, it is badly affected by that problem
example[5]: The economy was overloaded with so much debt that a real depression was possible.
